column2: Chapter 35.
column3: Chapter thirty five.

column2: La Mazzolata.
column3: La Mazzolata.

column2: Gentlemen, said the Count of Monte Cristo as he entered, "I pray you excuse me for suffering my visit to be anticipated; but I feared to disturb you by presenting myself earlier at your apartments; besides, you sent me word that you would come to me, and I have held myself at your disposal."
column3: Gentlemen, said the Count of Monte Cristo as he entered, "I pray you excuse me for suffering my visit to be anticipated; but I feared to disturb you by presenting myself earlier at your apartments; besides, you sent me word that you would come to me, and I have held myself at your disposal."

column2: Franz and I have to thank you a thousand times, count, returned Albert; "you extricated us from a great dilemma, and we were on the point of inventing a very fantastic vehicle when your friendly invitation reached us."
column3: Franz and I have to thank you a thousand times, count, returned Albert; "you extricated us from a great dilemma, and we were on the point of inventing a very fantastic vehicle when your friendly invitation reached us."

column2: Indeed, returned the count, motioning the two young men to sit down. "It was the fault of that blockhead Pastrini, that I did not sooner assist you in your distress.
column3: Indeed, returned the count, motioning the two young men to sit down. "It was the fault of that blockhead Pastrini, that I did not sooner assist you in your distress.

column2: He did not mention a syllable of your embarrassment to me, when he knows that, alone and isolated as I am, I seek every opportunity of making the acquaintance of my neighbors.
column3: He did not mention a syllable of your embarrassment to me, when he knows that, alone and isolated as I am, I seek every opportunity of making the acquaintance of my neighbors.

column2: As soon as I learned I could in any way assist you, I most eagerly seized the opportunity of offering my services." The two young men bowed.
column3: As soon as I learned I could in any way assist you, I most eagerly seized the opportunity of offering my services." The two young men bowed.

column2: Franz had, as yet, found nothing to say; he had come to no determination, and as nothing in the count's manner manifested the wish that he should recognize him, he did not know whether to make any allusion to the past, or wait until he had more proof; besides, although sure it was he who had been in the box the previous evening, he could not be equally positive that this was the man he had seen at the Colosseum.
column3: Franz had, as yet, found nothing to say; he had come to no determination, and as nothing in the count's manner manifested the wish that he should recognize him, he did not know whether to make any allusion to the past, or wait until he had more proof; besides, although sure it was he who had been in the box the previous evening, he could not be equally positive that this was the man he had seen at the Colosseum.

column2: He resolved, therefore, to let things take their course without making any direct overture to the count.
column3: He resolved, therefore, to let things take their course without making any direct overture to the count.

column2: Moreover, he had this advantage, he was master of the count's secret, while the count had no hold on Franz, who had nothing to conceal.
column3: Moreover, he had this advantage, he was master of the count's secret, while the count had no hold on Franz, who had nothing to conceal.

column2: However, he resolved to lead the conversation to a subject which might possibly clear up his doubts.
column3: However, he resolved to lead the conversation to a subject which might possibly clear up his doubts.

column2: Count, said he, "you have offered us places in your carriage, and at your windows in the Rospoli Palace.
column3: Count, said he, "you have offered us places in your carriage, and at your windows in the Rospoli Palace.

column2: Can you tell us where we can obtain a sight of the Piazza del Popolo?"
column3: Can you tell us where we can obtain a sight of the Piazza del Popolo?"

column2: Ah, said the count negligently, looking attentively at Morcerf, "is there not something like an execution upon the Piazza del Popolo?"
column3: Ah, said the count negligently, looking attentively at Morcerf, "is there not something like an execution upon the Piazza del Popolo?"

column2: Yes, returned Franz, finding that the count was coming to the point he wished.
column3: Yes, returned Franz, finding that the count was coming to the point he wished.

column2: Stay, I think I told my steward yesterday to attend to this; perhaps I can render you this slight service also. He extended his hand, and rang the bell thrice.
column3: Stay, I think I told my steward yesterday to attend to this; perhaps I can render you this slight service also. He extended his hand, and rang the bell thrice.

column2: Did you ever occupy yourself, said he to Franz, "with the employment of time and the means of simplifying the summoning your servants?
column3: Did you ever occupy yourself, said he to Franz, "with the employment of time and the means of simplifying the summoning your servants?

column2: I have.
column3: I have.

column2: When I ring once, it is for my valet; twice, for my majordomo; thrice, for my steward,--thus I do not waste a minute or a word.
column3: When I ring once, it is for my valet; twice, for my majordomo; thrice, for my steward,--thus I do not waste a minute or a word.

column2: Here he is." A man of about forty-five or fifty entered, exactly resembling the smuggler who had introduced Franz into the cavern; but he did not appear to recognize him.
column3: Here he is." A man of about forty five or fifty entered, exactly resembling the smuggler who had introduced Franz into the cavern; but he did not appear to recognize him.

column2: It was evident he had his orders. "Monsieur Bertuccio," said the count, "you have procured me windows looking on the Piazza del Popolo, as I ordered you yesterday."
column3: It was evident he had his orders. "Monsieur Bertuccio," said the count, "you have procured me windows looking on the Piazza del Popolo, as I ordered you yesterday."

column2: Yes, excellency, returned the steward; "but it was very late."
column3: Yes, excellency, returned the steward; "but it was very late."

column2: Did I not tell you I wished for one? replied the count, frowning.
column3: Did I not tell you I wished for one? replied the count, frowning.

column2: And your excellency has one, which was let to Prince Lobanieff; but I was obliged to pay a hundred--
column3: And your excellency has one, which was let to Prince Lobanieff; but I was obliged to pay a hundred--

column2: That will do--that will do, Monsieur Bertuccio; spare these gentlemen all such domestic arrangements.	That will do-that will do, Monsieur Bertuccio; spare these gentlemen all such domestic arrangements.
column3: true

column2: You have the window, that is sufficient. Give orders to the coachman; and be in readiness on the stairs to conduct us to it." The steward bowed, and was about to quit the room. "Ah," continued the count, "be good enough to ask Pastrini if he has received the tavoletta, and if he can send us an account of the execution."
column3: You have the window, that is sufficient. Give orders to the coachman; and be in readiness on the stairs to conduct us to it." The steward bowed, and was about to quit the room. "Ah," continued the count, "be good enough to ask Pastrini if he has received the tavoletta, and if he can send us an account of the execution."

column2: There is no need to do that, said Franz, taking out his tablets; "for I saw the account, and copied it down."
column3: There is no need to do that, said Franz, taking out his tablets; "for I saw the account, and copied it down."

column2: Very well, you can retire, M. Bertuccio; but let us know when breakfast is ready.	Very well, you can retire, m Bertuccio; but let us know when breakfast is ready.
column3: false

column2: These gentlemen," added he, turning to the two friends, "will, I trust, do me the honor to breakfast with me?"
column3: These gentlemen," added he, turning to the two friends, "will, I trust, do me the honor to breakfast with me?"

column2: But, my dear count, said Albert, "we shall abuse your kindness."
column3: But, my dear count, said Albert, "we shall abuse your kindness."

column2: Not at all; on the contrary, you will give me great pleasure.	Not at all; on the contrary, you will give me great pleasure.
column3: true

column2: You will, one or other of you, perhaps both, return it to me at Paris.
column3: You will, one or other of you, perhaps both, return it to me at Paris.

column2: M. Bertuccio, lay covers for three." He then took Franz's tablets out of his hand.
column3: M. Bertuccio, lay covers for three." He then took Franz's tablets out of his hand.

column2: 'We announce,' he read, in the same tone with which he would have read a newspaper, 'that to-day, the 23d of February, will be executed Andrea Rondolo, guilty of murder on the person of the respected and venerated Don Cesare Torlini, canon of the church of St. John Lateran, and Peppino, called Rocca Priori, convicted of complicity with the detestable bandit Luigi Vampa, and the men of his band.' Hum! 'The first will be mazzolato, the second decapitato.' Yes, continued the count, "it was at first arranged in this way; but I think since yesterday some change has taken place in the order of the ceremony."
column3: 'We announce,' he read, in the same tone with which he would have read a newspaper, 'that to day, the twenty three d of February, will be executed Andrea Rondolo, guilty of murder on the person of the respected and venerated Don Cesare Torlini, canon of the church of saint John Lateran, and Peppino, called Rocca Priori, convicted of complicity with the detestable bandit Luigi Vampa, and the men of his band.' Hum! 'The first will be mazzolato, the second decapitato.' Yes, continued the count, "it was at first arranged in this way; but I think since yesterday some change has taken place in the order of the ceremony."

column2: Really? said Franz.
column3: Really? said Franz.

column2: Yes, I passed the evening at the Cardinal Rospigliosi's, and there mention was made of something like a pardon for one of the two men.
column3: Yes, I passed the evening at the Cardinal Rospigliosi's, and there mention was made of something like a pardon for one of the two men.

column2: For Andrea Rondolo? asked Franz.
column3: For Andrea Rondolo? asked Franz.

column2: No, replied the count, carelessly; "for the other (he glanced at the tablets as if to recall the name), for Peppino, called Rocca Priori.
column3: No, replied the count, carelessly; "for the other (he glanced at the tablets as if to recall the name), for Peppino, called Rocca Priori.

column2: You are thus deprived of seeing a man guillotined; but the mazzuola still remains, which is a very curious punishment when seen for the first time, and even the second, while the other, as you must know, is very simple.
column3: You are thus deprived of seeing a man guillotined; but the mazzuola still remains, which is a very curious punishment when seen for the first time, and even the second, while the other, as you must know, is very simple.

column2: The mandaia [*] never fails, never trembles, never strikes thirty times ineffectually, like the soldier who beheaded the Count of Chalais, and to whose tender mercy Richelieu had doubtless recommended the sufferer.
column3: The mandaia [asterisk] never fails, never trembles, never strikes thirty times ineffectually, like the soldier who beheaded the Count of Chalais, and to whose tender mercy Richelieu had doubtless recommended the sufferer.

column2: Ah," added the count, in a contemptuous tone, "do not tell me of European punishments, they are in the infancy, or rather the old age, of cruelty."
column3: Ah," added the count, in a contemptuous tone, "do not tell me of European punishments, they are in the infancy, or rather the old age, of cruelty."

column2: * Guillotine.
column3: asterisk Guillotine.

column2: Really, count, replied Franz, "one would think that you had studied the different tortures of all the nations of the world."
column3: Really, count, replied Franz, "one would think that you had studied the different tortures of all the nations of the world."

column2: There are, at least, few that I have not seen, said the count coldly.
column3: There are, at least, few that I have not seen, said the count coldly.

column2: And you took pleasure in beholding these dreadful spectacles?
column3: And you took pleasure in beholding these dreadful spectacles?

column2: My first sentiment was horror, the second indifference, the third curiosity.
column3: My first sentiment was horror, the second indifference, the third curiosity.

column2: Curiosity--that is a terrible word.
column3: Curiosity-that is a terrible word.

column2: Why so?	Why so?
column3: true

column2: In life, our greatest preoccupation is death; is it not then, curious to study the different ways by which the soul and body can part; and how, according to their different characters, temperaments, and even the different customs of their countries, different persons bear the transition from life to death, from existence to annihilation?
column3: In life, our greatest preoccupation is death; is it not then, curious to study the different ways by which the soul and body can part; and how, according to their different characters, temperaments, and even the different customs of their countries, different persons bear the transition from life to death, from existence to annihilation?

column2: As for myself, I can assure you of one thing,--the more men you see die, the easier it becomes to die yourself; and in my opinion, death may be a torture, but it is not an expiation."
column3: As for myself, I can assure you of one thing,--the more men you see die, the easier it becomes to die yourself; and in my opinion, death may be a torture, but it is not an expiation."

column2: I do not quite understand you, replied Franz; "pray explain your meaning, for you excite my curiosity to the highest pitch."
column3: I do not quite understand you, replied Franz; "pray explain your meaning, for you excite my curiosity to the highest pitch."

column2: Listen, said the count, and deep hatred mounted to his face, as the blood would to the face of any other.
column3: Listen, said the count, and deep hatred mounted to his face, as the blood would to the face of any other.

column2: If a man had by unheard-of and excruciating tortures destroyed your father, your mother, your betrothed,--a being who, when torn from you, left a desolation, a wound that never closes, in your breast,--do you think the reparation that society gives you is sufficient when it interposes the knife of the guillotine between the base of the occiput and the trapezal muscles of the murderer, and allows him who has caused us years of moral sufferings to escape with a few moments of physical pain?
column3: If a man had by unheard of and excruciating tortures destroyed your father, your mother, your betrothed,--a being who, when torn from you, left a desolation, a wound that never closes, in your breast,--do you think the reparation that society gives you is sufficient when it interposes the knife of the guillotine between the base of the occiput and the trapezal muscles of the murderer, and allows him who has caused us years of moral sufferings to escape with a few moments of physical pain?

column2: Yes, I know, said Franz, "that human justice is insufficient to console us; she can give blood in return for blood, that is all; but you must demand from her only what it is in her power to grant."
column3: Yes, I know, said Franz, "that human justice is insufficient to console us; she can give blood in return for blood, that is all; but you must demand from her only what it is in her power to grant."

column2: I will put another case to you, continued the count; "that where society, attacked by the death of a person, avenges death by death.
column3: I will put another case to you, continued the count; "that where society, attacked by the death of a person, avenges death by death.

column2: But are there not a thousand tortures by which a man may be made to suffer without society taking the least cognizance of them, or offering him even the insufficient means of vengeance, of which we have just spoken? Are there not crimes for which the impalement of the Turks, the augers of the Persians, the stake and the brand of the Iroquois Indians, are inadequate tortures, and which are unpunished by society?
column3: But are there not a thousand tortures by which a man may be made to suffer without society taking the least cognizance of them, or offering him even the insufficient means of vengeance, of which we have just spoken? Are there not crimes for which the impalement of the Turks, the augers of the Persians, the stake and the brand of the Iroquois Indians, are inadequate tortures, and which are unpunished by society?

column2: Answer me, do not these crimes exist?"
column3: Answer me, do not these crimes exist?"

column2: Yes, answered Franz; "and it is to punish them that duelling is tolerated."
column3: Yes, answered Franz; "and it is to punish them that duelling is tolerated."

column2: Ah, duelling, cried the count; "a pleasant manner, upon my soul, of arriving at your end when that end is vengeance!
column3: Ah, duelling, cried the count; "a pleasant manner, upon my soul, of arriving at your end when that end is vengeance!

column2: A man has carried off your mistress, a man has seduced your wife, a man has dishonored your daughter; he has rendered the whole life of one who had the right to expect from heaven that portion of happiness God has promised to every one of his creatures, an existence of misery and infamy; and you think you are avenged because you send a ball through the head, or pass a sword through the breast, of that man who has planted madness in your brain, and despair in your heart.
column3: A man has carried off your mistress, a man has seduced your wife, a man has dishonored your daughter; he has rendered the whole life of one who had the right to expect from heaven that portion of happiness God has promised to every one of his creatures, an existence of misery and infamy; and you think you are avenged because you send a ball through the head, or pass a sword through the breast, of that man who has planted madness in your brain, and despair in your heart.

column2: And remember, moreover, that it is often he who comes off victorious from the strife, absolved of all crime in the eyes of the world.
column3: And remember, moreover, that it is often he who comes off victorious from the strife, absolved of all crime in the eyes of the world.

column2: No, no," continued the count, "had I to avenge myself, it is not thus I would take revenge."
column3: No, no," continued the count, "had I to avenge myself, it is not thus I would take revenge."

column2: Then you disapprove of duelling?	Then you disapprove of duelling?
column3: false

column2: You would not fight a duel?" asked Albert in his turn, astonished at this strange theory.
column3: You would not fight a duel?" asked Albert in his turn, astonished at this strange theory.

column2: Oh, yes, replied the count; "understand me, I would fight a duel for a trifle, for an insult, for a blow; and the more so that, thanks to my skill in all bodily exercises, and the indifference to danger I have gradually acquired, I should be almost certain to kill my man.
column3: Oh, yes, replied the count; "understand me, I would fight a duel for a trifle, for an insult, for a blow; and the more so that, thanks to my skill in all bodily exercises, and the indifference to danger I have gradually acquired, I should be almost certain to kill my man.

column2: Oh, I would fight for such a cause; but in return for a slow, profound, eternal torture, I would give back the same, were it possible; an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, as the Orientalists say,--our masters in everything,--those favored creatures who have formed for themselves a life of dreams and a paradise of realities."
column3: Oh, I would fight for such a cause; but in return for a slow, profound, eternal torture, I would give back the same, were it possible; an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, as the Orientalists say,--our masters in everything,--those favored creatures who have formed for themselves a life of dreams and a paradise of realities."

column2: But, said Franz to the count, "with this theory, which renders you at once judge and executioner of your own cause, it would be difficult to adopt a course that would forever prevent your falling under the power of the law.
column3: But, said Franz to the count, "with this theory, which renders you at once judge and executioner of your own cause, it would be difficult to adopt a course that would forever prevent your falling under the power of the law.

column2: Hatred is blind, rage carries you away; and he who pours out vengeance runs the risk of tasting a bitter draught."
column3: Hatred is blind, rage carries you away; and he who pours out vengeance runs the risk of tasting a bitter draught."

column2: Yes, if he be poor and inexperienced, not if he be rich and skilful; besides, the worst that could happen to him would be the punishment of which we have already spoken, and which the philanthropic French Revolution has substituted for being torn to pieces by horses or broken on the wheel.	Yes, if he be poor and inexperienced, not if he be rich and skilful; besides, the worst that could happen to him would be the punishment of which we have already spoken, and which the philanthropic French Revolution has substituted for being torn to pieces by horses or broken on the wheel.

column2: What matters this punishment, as long as he is avenged?
column3: What matters this punishment, as long as he is avenged?

column2: On my word, I almost regret that in all probability this miserable Peppino will not be beheaded, as you might have had an opportunity then of seeing how short a time the punishment lasts, and whether it is worth even mentioning; but, really this is a most singular conversation for the Carnival, gentlemen; how did it arise?
column3: On my word, I almost regret that in all probability this miserable Peppino will not be beheaded, as you might have had an opportunity then of seeing how short a time the punishment lasts, and whether it is worth even mentioning; but, really this is a most singular conversation for the Carnival, gentlemen; how did it arise?

column2: Ah, I recollect, you asked for a place at my window; you shall have it; but let us first sit down to table, for here comes the servant to inform us that breakfast is ready." As he spoke, a servant opened one of the four doors of the apartment, saying--"Al suo commodo!" The two young men arose and entered the breakfast-room.
column3: Ah, I recollect, you asked for a place at my window; you shall have it; but let us first sit down to table, for here comes the servant to inform us that breakfast is ready." As he spoke, a servant opened one of the four doors of the apartment, saying-"Al s u o commodo!" The two young men arose and entered the breakfast room.

column2: During the meal, which was excellent, and admirably served, Franz looked repeatedly at Albert, in order to observe the impressions which he doubted not had been made on him by the words of their entertainer; but whether with his usual carelessness he had paid but little attention to him, whether the explanation of the Count of Monte Cristo with regard to duelling had satisfied him, or whether the events which Franz knew of had had their effect on him alone, he remarked that his companion did not pay the least regard to them, but on the contrary ate like a man who for the last four or five months had been condemned to partake of Italian cookery--that is, the worst in the world.
column3: During the meal, which was excellent, and admirably served, Franz looked repeatedly at Albert, in order to observe the impressions which he doubted not had been made on him by the words of their entertainer; but whether with his usual carelessness he had paid but little attention to him, whether the explanation of the Count of Monte Cristo with regard to duelling had satisfied him, or whether the events which Franz knew of had had their effect on him alone, he remarked that his companion did not pay the least regard to them, but on the contrary ate like a man who for the last four or five months had been condemned to partake of Italian cookery-that is, the worst in the world.

column2: As for the count, he just touched the dishes; he seemed to fulfil the duties of a host by sitting down with his guests, and awaited their departure to be served with some strange or more delicate food.
column3: As for the count, he just touched the dishes; he seemed to fulfil the duties of a host by sitting down with his guests, and awaited their departure to be served with some strange or more delicate food.

column2: This brought back to Franz, in spite of himself, the recollection of the terror with which the count had inspired the Countess G----, and her firm conviction that the man in the opposite box was a vampire.
column3: This brought back to Franz, in spite of himself, the recollection of the terror with which the count had inspired the Countess G----, and her firm conviction that the man in the opposite box was a vampire.

column2: At the end of the breakfast Franz took out his watch.
column3: At the end of the breakfast Franz took out his watch.

column2: Well, said the count, "what are you doing?"
column3: Well, said the count, "what are you doing?"

column2: You must excuse us, count, returned Franz, "but we have still much to do."
column3: You must excuse us, count, returned Franz, "but we have still much to do."

column2: What may that be?
column3: What may that be?

column2: We have no masks, and it is absolutely necessary to procure them.
column3: We have no masks, and it is absolutely necessary to procure them.

column2: Do not concern yourself about that; we have, I think, a private room in the Piazza del Popolo; I will have whatever costumes you choose brought to us, and you can dress there.
column3: Do not concern yourself about that; we have, I think, a private room in the Piazza del Popolo; I will have whatever costumes you choose brought to us, and you can dress there.

column2: After the execution? cried Franz.
column3: After the execution? cried Franz.

column2: Before or after, whichever you please.
column3: Before or after, whichever you please.

column2: Opposite the scaffold?
column3: Opposite the scaffold?

column2: The scaffold forms part of the fete.
column3: The scaffold forms part of the fete.

column2: Count, I have reflected on the matter, said Franz, "I thank you for your courtesy, but I shall content myself with accepting a place in your carriage and at your window at the Rospoli Palace, and I leave you at liberty to dispose of my place at the Piazza del Popolo."
column3: Count, I have reflected on the matter, said Franz, "I thank you for your courtesy, but I shall content myself with accepting a place in your carriage and at your window at the Rospoli Palace, and I leave you at liberty to dispose of my place at the Piazza del Popolo."

column2: But I warn you, you will lose a very curious sight, returned the count.
column3: But I warn you, you will lose a very curious sight, returned the count.

column2: You will describe it to me, replied Franz, "and the recital from your lips will make as great an impression on me as if I had witnessed it.
column3: You will describe it to me, replied Franz, "and the recital from your lips will make as great an impression on me as if I had witnessed it.

column2: I have more than once intended witnessing an execution, but I have never been able to make up my mind; and you, Albert?"
column3: I have more than once intended witnessing an execution, but I have never been able to make up my mind; and you, Albert?"

column2: I, replied the viscount,--"I saw Castaing executed, but I think I was rather intoxicated that day, for I had quitted college the same morning, and we had passed the previous night at a tavern."
column3: I, replied the viscount,--"I saw Castaing executed, but I think I was rather intoxicated that day, for I had quitted college the same morning, and we had passed the previous night at a tavern."

column2: Besides, it is no reason because you have not seen an execution at Paris, that you should not see one anywhere else; when you travel, it is to see everything.	Besides, it is no reason because you have not seen an execution at Paris, that you should not see one anywhere else; when you travel, it is to see everything.
column3: true

column2: Think what a figure you will make when you are asked, 'How do they execute at Rome?' and you reply, 'I do not know'!
column3: Think what a figure you will make when you are asked, 'How do they execute at Rome?' and you reply, 'I do not know'!

column2: And, besides, they say that the culprit is an infamous scoundrel, who killed with a log of wood a worthy canon who had brought him up like his own son.
column3: And, besides, they say that the culprit is an infamous scoundrel, who killed with a log of wood a worthy canon who had brought him up like his own son.

column2: Diable, when a churchman is killed, it should be with a different weapon than a log, especially when he has behaved like a father.
column3: Diable, when a churchman is killed, it should be with a different weapon than a log, especially when he has behaved like a father.

column2: If you went to Spain, would you not see the bull-fight?
column3: If you went to Spain, would you not see the bull fight?

column2: Well, suppose it is a bull-fight you are going to see?
column3: Well, suppose it is a bull fight you are going to see?

column2: Recollect the ancient Romans of the Circus, and the sports where they killed three hundred lions and a hundred men.
column3: Recollect the ancient romans of the Circus, and the sports where they killed three hundred lions and a hundred men.

column2: Think of the eighty thousand applauding spectators, the sage matrons who took their daughters, and the charming Vestals who made with the thumb of their white hands the fatal sign that said, 'Come, despatch the dying.'"
column3: Think of the eighty thousand applauding spectators, the sage matrons who took their daughters, and the charming Vestals who made with the thumb of their white hands the fatal sign that said, 'Come, despatch the dying.'"

column2: Shall you go, then, Albert? asked Franz.
column3: Shall you go, then, Albert? asked Franz.

column2: Ma foi, yes; like you, I hesitated, but the count's eloquence decides me.
column3: Ma foi, yes; like you, I hesitated, but the count's eloquence decides me.

column2: Let us go, then, said Franz, "since you wish it; but on our way to the Piazza del Popolo, I wish to pass through the Corso.
column3: Let us go, then, said Franz, "since you wish it; but on our way to the Piazza del Popolo, I wish to pass through the Corso.

column2: Is this possible, count?"
column3: Is this possible, count?"

column2: On foot, yes, in a carriage, no.
column3: On foot, yes, in a carriage, no

column2: I will go on foot, then.
column3: I will go on foot, then.

column2: Is it important that you should go that way?
column3: Is it important that you should go that way?

column2: Yes, there is something I wish to see.
column3: Yes, there is something I wish to see.

column2: Well, we will go by the Corso.	Well, we will go by the Corso.

column2: We will send the carriage to wait for us on the Piazza del Popolo, by the Strada del Babuino, for I shall be glad to pass, myself, through the Corso, to see if some orders I have given have been executed."

column2: Well, asked Franz, "what think you of the Count of Monte Cristo?"
column3: Well, asked Franz, "what think you of the Count of Monte Cristo?"

column2: What do I think? said Albert, evidently surprised at such a question from his companion; "I think he is a delightful fellow, who does the honors of his table admirably; who has travelled much, read much, is, like Brutus, of the Stoic school, and moreover," added he, sending a volume of smoke up towards the ceiling, "that he has excellent cigars." Such was Albert's opinion of the count, and as Franz well knew that Albert professed never to form an opinion except upon long reflection, he made no attempt to change it.

column2: But, said he, "did you observe one very singular thing?"

column2: Ah, replied he, sighing, "that is not very surprising; I have been more than a year absent from Paris, and my clothes are of a most antiquated cut; the count takes me for a provincial.

column2: Come, we have not any time to lose, it is half-past twelve--let us set off." All three descended; the coachman received his master's orders, and drove down the Via del Babuino. While the three gentlemen walked along the Piazza de Spagni and the Via Frattina, which led directly between the Fiano and Rospoli palaces, Franz's attention was directed towards the windows of that last palace, for he had not forgotten the signal agreed upon between the man in the mantle and the Transtevere peasant.

column2: As they approached the Piazza del Popolo, the crowd became more dense, and above the heads of the multitude two objects were visible: the obelisk, surmounted by a cross, which marks the centre of the square, and in front of the obelisk, at the point where the three streets, del Babuino, del Corso, and di Ripetta, meet, the two uprights of the scaffold, between which glittered the curved knife of the mandaia.

column2: At the corner of the street they met the count's steward, who was awaiting his master. column2: On chairs were laid elegant masquerade costumes of blue and white satin.

column2: As you left the choice of your costumes to me, said the count to the two friends, "I have had these brought, as they will be the most worn this year; and they are most suitable, on account of the confetti (sweetmeats), as they do not show the flour."

column2: It was the first time Franz had ever seen a guillotine,--we say guillotine, because the Roman mandaia is formed on almost the same model as the French instrument.

column2: Two men, seated on the movable plank on which the victim is laid, were eating their breakfasts, while waiting for the criminal. Their repast consisted apparently of bread and sausages.

column3: One of them lifted the plank, took out a flask of wine, drank some, and then passed it to his companion.

column2: The prisoners, transported the previous evening from the Carcere Nuovo to the little church of Santa Maria del Popolo, had passed the night, each accompanied by two priests, in a chapel closed by a grating, before which were two sentinels, who were relieved at intervals.

column2: Many women held their infants on their shoulders, and thus the children had the best view. column2: I will not die alone--I will not!" And he broke from the priests struggling and raving like a wild beast, and striving desperately to break the cords that bound his hands.

column2: Lead two sheep to the butcher's, two oxen to the slaughterhouse, and make one of them understand that his companion will not die; the sheep will bleat for pleasure, the ox will bellow with joy.
